Check out a beautiful book from the 2017 Klaus Flugge Prize shortlist

Written by Sophie Green · Published Sep 13, 2017

The Klaus Flugge Prize recognises promising and exciting newcomers to children‚Äôs picture book illustration. Named after the influential children‚Äôs book publisher who founded Andersen Press, which specialises in picture books and children‚Äôs fiction, it is now in its second year, with the winner being announced today (13 September)

Last year‚Äôs winner was Hector and the Hummingbird, by Nicholas John Frith, a story about a quiet bear and his noisy best friend.

The Journey, by Francesca Sanna

Already a winner of the 2017 Amnesty CILIP Honours and a UK Literacy Association Award, author/Illustrator Francesca Sanna was inspired to write this, her first picture book, after meeting two girls in a refugee centre in Italy:

‚ÄúWith haunting echoes of current affairs, this beautifully illustrated book explores the unimaginable decisions made as a family leave their home and everything they know to escape the turmoil and tragedy brought by war.‚Äù

Little Red, by Bethan Woollvin

This bold retelling of Little Red Riding Hood won the prestigious Macmillan Prize 2014 for Children‚Äôs Picture Book Illustration, and was named as one of the New York Times Best Illustrated Children‚Äôs Books of 2016:

‚ÄúLittle Red Riding Hood meets a wolf on her way through the woods to visit her sick grandmother. The wolf is hungry, and Red Riding Hood looks tasty, so he hatches a dastardly plan, gobbles up Grandma and lies in wait.

‚ÄúSo far, so familiar. But this Little Red Riding Hood is not easily fooled, and this big bad wolf better watch his back.‚Äù

The Museum of Me, by Emma Lewis

Winner of the Opera Prima Award at this years Bologna Children‚Äôs Book Fair, Emma Lewis‚Äôs collage of mixed-media illustrations looks at museums and their value and what the things we collect, and the reasons we collect them, tell us about ourselves:

‚ÄúThis work follows a little girl on a journey of discovery to find out what museums are and what they hold in store. Brimming with anticipation, our young protagonist encounters giant bugs and peculiar beasts; ancient pots and contemporary paitings; feathery leaves and flowers as big as her own head!‚Äù

First Snow, by Bomi Park

‚ÄúLook out. Now look up. From the sky one flake falls, then another. And just like that - it‚Äôs snowing. In this beautiful book from debut creator Bomi Park, a young girl wakes up to the year‚Äôs first snowy day. From her initial glimpse out the window to her poignant adventures - rolling a snowman, making snow angels - the girl‚Äôs quiet quests are ones all young readers will recognise. Simple, muted text and exquisite, evocative art conjure the excitement of a day spent exploring the wonder of snow - and the magic that, sometimes literally, such a day brings.‚Äù

Hannah and Sugar, by Kate Berube

Winner of the Literary Arts Oregon Book Award and the Eloise Jarvis McGraw Award for Children‚Äôs Literature, this is a tale of fear, empathy and bravery:

‚ÄúEvery day after school, Hannah‚Äôs school bus is greeted by her classmate‚Äôs dog, Sugar. All of the other kids love Sugar, but Hannah just can‚Äôt conquer her fear of dogs. Then, one day, Sugar goes missing, so Hannah joins the search with her classmates. Will Hannah find a way to be brave, and make a new friend in the process?‚Äù

Sophie Green

I work for the Suffolk Libraries stock team. I also write children‚Äôs fiction, short stories and comedy. Visit my website.
